Original_notes: (-); “but the slightest knowledge of the theory of rotation of crops”
“annually export large quantities of millet, semsem, beans and peas” to exchange for brass wire
(+); Testamentary disposition [underlined] – subject to approval by the clan of the deceased, a severe limitation
(-); Full-time [underlined]; “professional” dentist for tooth extraction could hardly have been full-time. But Lango witch-doctors might have been professional
and usually not adopted, liberated, or killed [underlined] – usually adopted or married very soon
(-); ref. to this – Driberg (1923: 173) – but must be quite rare
(-); there is free polygyny, each man taking as many as he can afford
celebrations of the upper classes [underlined]; highly skilled musicians perform at public ceremonies
Chiefs and war-leaders are buried outside the village, ordinary persons inside it
(-); some controversy on this point – Driberg (1923: 205) thinks there was nothing beyond temporary alliances in over 200 years.
certain offenses are compoundable, but only to the offended party
(+); seemingly an informal role, but war-leaders are recognized at death by special burial practice
3 separate columns, each divided into companies
(+); ornaments [underlined]; appellations [underlined]; war-names are given at the victory feast
